channel.title: Shooting birds game type
channel.description: I've decided to write a game where you can shoot birds that fly by with your mouse (the target icon). I drew the target icon using graphics2D, but i don't know how to draw a bird, or even draw a bird using a sprite and make the wings move. Mainly, I do not know how to give sprites animations.

[quote=“sfix, post:6, topic:439344”]The math for rotating your player towards the mouse goes something like this:

float x_diff = character.x - (float) mouse_x; float y_diff = character.y - (float) mouse_y; float theta = Math.atan2(x_diff, y_diff); float angle = theta * (180 / Math.PI); g2d.rotate(-angle); [/quote]

Looking at the trig you have there to make sure its right but you don’t need to convert the angle to degrees. The graphics 2d objects’ rotate method uses radians.

[quote=“imsuperman05, post:5, topic:439344”][quote author=sfix link=topic=542039.msg3972182#msg3972182 date=1334268950]

Does that mean I would need to have a sprite for each movement?

Yes.
[/quote]
What if, for example, I wanted to write some type of shooting game where you control the gun with your mouse and zombies move after you? How would I go about even getting the sprites first of all? And would it still be simple to use the sprites per movement?[/quote]

Sorry for the delayed reply. Haha, seems like everyone’s wrote a top-down zombie shooter :p. Yes, it only takes 6-8 sprites per animation, and you can apply 2d transformations (rotation, translation, etc.) to make your character face the correct direction.

The math for rotating your player towards the mouse goes something like this:

float x_diff = character.x - (float) mouse_x;
float y_diff = character.y - (float) mouse_y;
float theta = Math.atan2(x_diff, y_diff);
float angle = theta * (180 / Math.PI);
g2d.rotate(-angle);

item.title: Shooting birds game type
item.dc:creator: @sfix sfix
item.description:
@sfix wrote:

Your simplest option is to use a sprite sheet and create a different image for each frame.

BufferedImage sheet = ImageIO.read(new File("sheet.png"));
int width = 30, height = sheet.getHeight(); //30px
BufferedImage[] frames = new BufferedImage[sheet.getWidth() / width];
for(int i = 0; i < frames.length; i++) {
    frames[i] = sheet.getSubimage(i * width, 0, width, height);
}

And inside your player model you could keep track of the current animation & frame and when you draw updates do:

g2d.drawImage(player.animation().nextFrame(), x, y, null);

edit: http://gamedev.moparisthebest.com/smf/index.php/topic,542101.msg3971833.html#new
